title: feat: call Filesystem::destroy when unmount the filesystem
build: update tempfile minver to fix dependency bot alarm
body: fix https://github.com/Sherlock-Holo/fuse3/security/dependabot/1

title: add unmount support
body:
- when drop `MountHandle`, will unmount in background task
- when call `MountHandle::unmount`, will wait unmount completely

title: feat: replace async-trait crate with AFIT feature
Fix dependency version specs
body:
Also, make the following CI changes:

* Test with -Zdirect-minimal-versions
* Use the cargo cache
* Use "cargo check" instead of "cargo build", since there are no tests anyway

title: Remove nix's unused "user" feature, except on Linux.
Update FreeBSD CI image
body: 12.4 will be EoL at the end of the month.  Use the oldest still-supported release.

title: Raise the Nix dependency to 0.27.0
body: The motivation is simply to reduce duplicate crate builds in a downstream consumer.

title: Clippy cleanup
body:
* unnecessary_cast
* redundant_async_block

title: feat: add write_flags arguments in the write method
body: add `write_flags` in the `write` method, user can use it check if the write operation is a delay write or not

title: Fixed fuse setxattr body length is not right error
body:
Fixed error "body length is not right" when handling any FUSE_SETXATTR request.
Before fix, we checked size of full payload "Name"+"Value", but setxattr.size field specifies only size of "Value" field.
Moved size check procedure down to proper place after payload splitting to "Name" and "Value".
Now we compare setxattr.size field with size of "Value" field.

title: Drop minor version dependency for nix.
body:
nix 0.26.1 contains bugs and mainline contains pull requests for unsound behavior. It seems unnecessary to track a specific minor version so just depend on 0.26.x instead.

If this seems OK, could you also bump the release version and push to crates.io for me?

title: fix: example memfs hard link fail
Remove connection writable wait
body:
https://github.com/Sherlock-Holo/fuse3/issues/4#issuecomment-1379976922
we check the kernel codes that the /dev/fuse is always writable, there's
no need to use AsyncFd(tokio)/Async(async-std) to check if the /dev/fuse
fd is writable or not

title: fix mount with tokio-runtime and nonempty = true
body:
This fix can be verified with the helloworld example. Without the fix, it complains about the mountpoint not being empty even when it is:

```shellSession
$ mkdir /tmp/mountpoint
$ cargo run --bin helloworld -- /tmp/mountpoint
...
thread 'main' panicked at 'called `Result::unwrap()` on an `Err` value: Os { code: 2, kind: NotFound, message: "No such file or directory" }', examples/src/helloworld/main.rs:336:10
...
```

The problem is that, on an empty dir, `read_dir(mount_path).await?.next_entry().await` returns `Ok(None)`, but the nonempty check only makes sense if it finds `Ok(Some(...))`. I was going to write this check as `.is_ok_and(Option::is_some)` instead, but `Result::is_ok_and` is unstable.

@KongzhangHao FYI: It appears that this issue was introduced in #53.

title: refactor: update msrv and fix cargo clippy warn
Replace dependency on tokio-stream with function call.
body: This is removing an unnecessary crate dependency with no loss of readability.

title: Update CI environment to FreeBSD 12.4
body: 12.3 will soon be EoL

title: Raise Nix dependency to 0.26.1
body: It makes no difference to fuse3 itself, but it allows consuming crates to potentially build fewer versions of Nix.

title: Fix nix
body: this pr should fix https://github.com/Sherlock-Holo/fuse3/issues/45

title: Don't exit early after FUSE_FORGET of the root inode
body:
Exiting early prevents the file system from ever receiving FUSE_DESTROY.
Plus, FUSE_FORGET for the root inode can happen for at least two reasons
other than an impending unmount:

* An unmount attempt that fails with EBUSY
* Extreme vnode pressure, theoretically

title: Make Session::mount semi-synchronous
body:
Session::mount will now return a Future that completes when the mount
does, whose result is another Future that completes when the file system
is unmounted.  This allows consumers to know whether the mount succeeded
without waiting for a future unmount.

Fixes #27

title: Factor out some common code in Session::inner_mount
build: update examples mio dep version
Implement more mount options
body:
* Change read_only to a bool instead of an option and implement as a
  flag
* Implement more mount options

title: Update FreeBSD CI image
body: FreeBSD 12.2 is EoL

title: Use no-consuming methods for MountOptions
body:
The consuming methods make for a nice compact syntax - as long as the
programmer knows exactly which methods will be needed.  But if some
mount options depend on runtime options then the consuming methods are
awkward:

```
let mut opts = MountOptions::default();
if let Some(foo) = cli.bar {
    opts = opts.custom_options(foo)
}
```

Non-consuming options, while requiring 1 more line in the simplest case,
are more flexible.

While I'm here, remove some extraneous clone()s.

title: Don't use the cargo-cache in CI
body: It doesn't actually work unless we check in a Cargo.lock file.

title: By default return ENOSYS for FUSE_OPENDIR
body:
This makes it work nicely with FUSE_NO_OPENDIR_SUPPORT and mirrors the
behavior for FUSE_OPEN.

title: Add a minimal CI setup
body: Fixes #8

title: Fix FUSE_LISTXATTR with size=0
body:
With size=0, the file system should reply with the size of the list and
errno 0.  errno ERANGE should only be used if the request had a nonzero
size that was too small.

title: derive Default for Request
body: It's helpful when unit testing a fuse3-based file system.

title: Change ReplyWrite.written to 32 bits
body:
The fuse_write_in struct only uses 32 bits to request the size of the
write, so there's no point to allocating 64 bits for the response.

title: Change setxattr's value argument to a &[u8]
body:
It's perfectly valid for an extended attribute to have binary data with
one, many, or no NUL characters.  fuse3 therefore can't convert it into
an OsString.  Pass the byte slice to the file system instead.

Fixes #14

title: Use a simpler timestamp structure for SetAttr too
body:
SystemTime is problematic for two reason:
* If the kernel tries to set a timestamp that predates the Epoch, fuse3
  would sign-cast it to a very large positive value.
* It's awkward for raw file systems to deal with SystemTime, since they
  really just want the secs and nsecs.

PR #7 changed the timestamp for GetAttr, this changes it for SetAttr too

title: Allow non-sequential directory offsets
body:
The FUSE protocol allows each directory entry to include a off field in
struct fuse_dirent. It's purpose is to uniquely identify a directory
entry so that a future FUSE_READDIR operation may continue where a
previous one left off. The FUSE file system is allowed to choose the
format of those off values. In particular, sequentially increasing
indexes are usually not adequate, because if a directory entry is
deleted in between two FUSE_READDIR operations, using sequential off
values could lead to skipping over a directory entry.

Instead of attempting to manage those offsets with fuse3, forcing them
to be sequential, pass responsibility to the file system.

Fixes #12

title: Correct the spelling of the "statfs" method.
Document that getxattr *must* return ERANGE if the size is insufficient
body:
The FUSE protocol specifies that the response to FUSE_GETXATTR is a data
buffer without header when sending data, or a struct fuse_getxattr_out
when sending the attribute's size.  However, since the data buffer does
not include a header it is impossible for the kernel to distinguish
between a struct fuse_getxattr_out and a data buffer if exactly the same
size.  Therefore, FUSE servers must always return ERANGE if the provided
size was insufficient.

title: Use a simpler timestamp structure for raw::reply::FileAttr
body:
SystemTime is problematic for two reasons:
* Before being serialized for FUSE fuse3 converts it to a Duration,
  which prohibits timestamps older than the Epoch.
* It's awkward for raw file systems to represent times as SystemTime if
  they internally serialize them in some other format.

This commit fixes both issues for raw file systems.  The first issue
applies to path file systems too, but this commit does not change it.

Fixes #6

title: Update Nix to the latest, which changes error types
body:
Nix 0.22.0 implements From in both directions between Nix::Error and
io::Error.

title: Port to FreeBSD
body:
* Use a newer Nix, with nmount support.
* Use nmount on FreeBSD instead of mount.
* Deal with 16-bit mode_t
* Disable fallocate in some examples, not yet supported by FreeBSD's fusefs
* Do nothing special to mount without privileges on FreeBSD.  Unlike Linux,
  it will just work if the system is configured to allow it.
* Open /dev/fuse with O_NONBLOCK, rather than setting it later.
* Set fs_name in one of the examples, for demonstration purposes.

Note: FreeBSD 14.0-CURRENT is required, with a build from
7b8622fa220b9c08041102f638f848c48e022644 or later.
